description: Numbers n giving rise to prime quadruples (30n+11, 30n+13, 30n+17, 30n+19).
comments: Intersection of A089160 and A089161. - _Zak Seidov_, Dec 22 2006Solutions of the equation (30*n+11)'+(30*n+13)'+(30*n+17)'+(30*n+19)'=4, where n' is the arithmetic derivative of n. [_Paolo P. Lava_, Nov 15 2012]This can be seen as a condensed version of A007530, which lists the first member of the actual prime quadruplet (30x+11, 30x+13, 30x+17, 30x+19), x=a(n). - _M. F. Hasler_, Dec 05 2013
links: Zak Seidov and Michael De Vlieger, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10972 (first 1000 terms from Zak Seidov)
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Prime Quadruplet.
mathematica: a014561Q[n_Integer] :=  If[And[PrimeQ[30 n + 11], PrimeQ[30 n + 13], PrimeQ[30 n + 17],     PrimeQ[30 n + 19]] == True, True, False];a014561[n_Integer] :=  Flatten[Position[Thread[a014561Q[Range[n]]], True]];a014561[1000] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jul 17 2014 *)
prog: (PARI) isok(n) = isprime(30*n+11) && isprime(30*n+13) && isprime(30*n+17) && isprime(30*n+19) \\ _Michel Marcus_, Jun 09 2013
author: _Eric W. Weisstein_
